Posted By: Stray_Dog (4/30/2010 5:20:11 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I run 4x this in my U/B deck, and it's perhaps one of the most efficient cards in the deck. I cannot over-emphasize the number of games I've one simply by mana-screwing my opponent in the early game, or even the entire time. Seriously, I've had a lot of games where my opponent's entire hand is backed up and unplayable because I screw him out of one kind of mana; Jund especially gets hosed by this thing. The fact that it replaces itself is just icing on the cake.  
  
Also, it's hilarious when your opponent is so happy to get a man-land...only for it to turn into an island.

Posted By: stagchest (12/23/2010 2:32:14 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
With the prevalence of [Valakut](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Valakut) Ramp this is an amazing sideboard card for any deck playing blue. This is by far the cheapest and easiest way in standard to stop a special land.
  
   
Whether it is maindeck playable depends on the metagame. While it does cantrip, that still slows you down by 2 mana for an effect which against mono or blue/x decks seems marginal. However, it can often shut down a secondary color.
  
   
6 Top 8 standard decks at Worlds 2010 played blue. 5 of the 6 these played 4x main-deck. That puts it just behind [Jace, the Mind Sculptor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace, the Mind Sculptor), [Preordain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Preordain), and [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak) which were 4x in all 6.
  
   
   
The [Stormtide Leviathan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stormtide Leviathan) others have mentioned doesn't need this since it makes its own islands.
posts.html:
With the prevalence of Valakut Ramp this is an amazing sideboard card for any deck playing blue. This is by far the cheapest and easiest way in standard to stop a special land.

Whether it is maindeck playable depends on the metagame. While it does cantrip, that still slows you down by 2 mana for an effect which against mono or blue/x decks seems marginal. However, it can often shut down a secondary color.

6 Top 8 standard decks at Worlds 2010 played blue. 5 of the 6 these played 4x main-deck. That puts it just behind Jace, the Mind Sculptor, Preordain, and Mana Leak which were 4x in all 6.


The Stormtide Leviathan others have mentioned doesn't need this since it makes its own islands.

The fact that right now any serious deck in constructed with U has four of these speaks for its self. It's not any of the abilities individually, but the combined effect, and for the cost. Absolutely love it.

Posted By: AXER (9/3/2010 8:06:36 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: For several months, this was widely agreed to be be the best blue card in standard. Better than Jace, the Mind Sculptor. Simply because two spreading seas in hand was a complete death draw for the powerhouse known as Jund, whereas Jace doesn't actually do that much in that matchup. It will still be good once Alara rotates, never fear- the worldwake manlands have seen to that. The cantrip also makes two-mana hands you would normally mulligan much more keepable, too.
posts.html:
